text: you know Passover isn't just about Seder
I know you guys know that and during
Passover you can't eat leavened bread
I'm sure you all know that and you know
how obsessed I am with breading chicken
cutlets this year
so today I'm gonna bread my chicken
cutlets with crushed up matzah it's
perfect for really any time but
particularly during Passover this is
eight whole matzah so that I crushed up
into crumbs but some of the pieces are
kind of big which is why I'm going with
crushing my own matzah into crumbs as
opposed to something like a matzo meal
add about two teaspoons of salt to the
crushed up matzo and about a quarter
teaspoon of pepper I've whisked an egg
to help decoding it here and I have four
chicken cutlets now you can increase or
decrease this recipe as you want the
original recipe is just for four so it's
one cutlet per person but these are nice
big cutlets coat them in egg both sides
and then in your crushed up matzah turn
to coat I like to turn my cutlets a
couple times to get a really nice
coating sometimes on the first try
it doesn't get fully coated and honestly
this is what I usually do cover it up
and then Pat it really nicely to it here
as much as possible these sort of bigger
pieces of matzah get really crunchy and
golden brown when you fry them so you
can just set them aside as you finish
them it's possible you may not need all
of these crumbs so if you want to put
about 2 cups of crumbs into your pie
plate to start off with then you can
save the other crumbs if you don't end
up using them you want to add a little
bit of flavor to this you could add some
chopped up nuts to the mixture if you
wanted to now what you want to do is get
about a half an inch of oil preheating
in your pan so that you can fry these
sure you could bake them but the frying
is gonna make them so delicious
don't deprive yourself of the
deliciousness that is a fried cutlet
all right let's fry
so over here I have my oil it's about a
half an inch of oil in a really nice big
cast-iron skillet that's what I like to
fry in it should be about 375 degrees I
like to drop in just a little bit of
whatever my coating is and make sure
that it sizzles and like turns golden in
about 15 to 30 seconds it's nice and
sizzle II then you can add your chicken
depending on the size of your skillet
you can add two maybe three at a time
but I'm just gonna go for two because
I'm gonna have to work in batches no
matter what so depending on the
thickness of your cutlets you could cook
these for about two minutes per side
might need a little bit more time these
are kind of thick they might need three
minutes so technically the oil temp
should be between 375 and like 350 at
the lowest but I think the crumb method
of testing is just fine these are
looking really golden and beautiful on
the first side turn them over the second
side may not take quite as long because
your chicken is cooked quite a bit so
you don't want to overcook it that's
like the worst thing you can do to a
chicken cutlet is overcook it remove and
then drain on paper towels and you can
do your next facts
you can make Cretan parm out of these
why don't you do that I would be delish
your favorites made of sauce a little
bit of cheese done that's it they're
done golden brown and crunchy now you
could do my amazing idea of making them
into a chicken parm which would be
really fantastic can you believe how
golden and crunchy they are
these are nice big ones so one per
person is definitely a nice dinner
serving but I'm just gonna simply serve
these with lemon wedges which is a
really great accompaniment offsets the
richness these are so fantastic I would
venture to guess that you will continue
making them long after Passover is over
